issue.title: Improve logging information when classes in configuration are the invalid type
issue.body:
There are several configuration values that are meant to be a FQCN string that implements an expected interface. Currently if the class does not implement the correct type a generic message is output but does not specify which entry is invalid. We should improve this and if an invalid class is configured we specify _which_ value is invalid.

- [ ] Definition providers
- [ ] Parameter stores
- [ ] Observers

issue.title: Bootstrapping configuration ddoes not respect ContainerAnalyticsObserver types
Logging analytics with default bootstrapping logger assumes PSR log processing is available
Logging definition provider should detail what instances are wrapped by CompositeDefinitionProvider

commits.message:
Task/improve logging composite definition provider (#301)

* Use correct reference to definitionProvider in logging context

* Add more logging when using composite definition provider

issue.title: Research avoiding multiple alias resolutions for the same abstract service
issue.body: It is possible that an abstract service is attempted to have its alias resolved that results in no alias resolutions. We should see if we can skip future checks for similar services since we know the resolution won't succeed. This happens because there are a list of `AliasDefinition` instances that could list the abstract service multiple times.

comment.body:
This could potentially have some value. We'd be saving iterating over service definitions needlessly during a part of the process that has not been optimized, relative to static analysis where caching drastically increases performance. However, it would involve adding and keeping up with state in the `StandardAliasDefinitionResolver`. Since this is a fairly low priority item I'm going to wait until, or if, more users could also see value out of doing this.

Will move this into the 2.x milestone.

issue.title: Deprecate the ConfigurationAttribute and corresponding implementation
issue.body:
When it was first conceived the `ConfigurationAttribute` was intended to handle a unique case for a type-safe configuration object. In practice the limitations place on this attribute make it hard to work with. Realistically, we don't need to have a separate interface for this. A type-safe configuration can be marked as a `#[Service]` or libraries using Annotated Container can implement their own attribute type and extend `ServiceAttribute`.

> Note this issue requires adjusting code in cspray/annotated-container-attribute
